Posts.Title: A rad onc weighs in on radiation "burns" Spinnerpom 53nancy

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2012 09:48AM Carrye wrote: Thanks for the clarification re the discourse of burns. I found the information on radiation side effects on this website to be of limited help to dark skinned women like myself. Sure we may not notice that we have turned red, but we do notice when we have turned charcoal black. I finished rads today. My radiated breast is 75% black. It looks, in the words of my white bff, charred. The black, charred dead outer layer of skin is starting to peel off. It would be great if the website operators would acknowledge the full range of skin color changes that commonly occur. My white radiation oncologist said my changes were very typical. Also, Due to my dark skin, i have never had a sunburn in my life so i also find the common description of radiation side effects as like a bad sunburn, so be of minimal help. Thanks to all and best wishes to all.
Posts.Title: A rad onc weighs in on radiation "burns" Spinnerpom 53nancy

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2012 10:07AM - edited Mar 14, 2012 10:09AM by Carrye judy There are a lot of issues. I did radiation with breath holding which involved a device similar to a scuba mask in my mouth, clips on my nose and a pair of goggles on my eyes throughehich i saw a computer monitor . This is offered to reduce radiation nicking the heart. It forces lung in front of the heart. I dont know how prone position could be combined with this. I have the impression that newer breath holding options and the latest more accurate rads delivery equipment alleviates some of the concerns that might suggest prone positioning. At my facility xrays were always taken pre rad delivery to make sure i was in the right position mapped out by the doc and physicists, All of this meant my pre boost rads took about 30 minutes. I never had the feeling anything was being done to save time . It took as long as it took. I had a lump. And didnt need axil rads. I think bet most doc just dont think there is an evidece basis for prone rads for typical breast cancer patients. What does the recent research say? The use of tatoos and other markings helpnthe technicians get our bodies into the precise position each time. If we gonupside down. On the table, how would that work.
Posts.Title: A rad onc weighs in on radiation "burns" Spinnerpom 53nancy

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2013 09:00PM Carrye wrote: My left breast "fatty necrosis " which i could not feel but showed up on routine mammagram and ultrasond in may 2011 was determined to be invasive cancer in november of 2011. I had lumpectomy and radiation. My painful hard pea lump in right breast in july 2012 turned out to an infected benign epidermal inclusion cyst. I had it surgcally removed after a course of antibiotics. Same surgeon performed both procedures. I was shocked to have these two unreleated experiences so close in time. There is no logic to breast diseases. Dont expect your body to Behave in predictable, rational ways.
Posts.Title: My Apologies, New lump Eliza22 Eliza22

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2012 12:29AM Carrye wrote: Research is inconclusive on value of chemo for node neg hormone pos hers neg with ontotype scores in intermediate range which is 18 to low 30's. Clinical trial dsta pending. My score was 15; my oncologist who is head of a major cancer center said risks outweighed benefits in my case. Your score puts you on boderline between low risk and intermediate. Tough choice to make!
Posts.Title: 58 y/o, Oncotype Score of 20, No Chemo Blessed58 shuf

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2012 11:32PM Carrye wrote: Radiation has been shown to increase surivival and decrease recurrence in the same breast. Radiation following lumpectomy is standard of care for that reason. Surgery cannot guarantee that every malignant cell has been removed. All it would take is one stray cancer cell to lead to another tumor. Ask your doctor to share the data on radiation so you can make a well informed decision.
Posts.Title: Radiation Necessary marystnow55 purple32

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2012 01:27PM Carrye wrote: The oncotype dx test looks at a number of genes to determine whether you are ar risk for recurrence. Tumor size is irrelevant. Anyone with a node negative , hormone postive, hers neg profile can use the oncotype score to help determine whether she will benefit from chemotherapy. Studies have shown quite conclusively that people with scores below 18 do not benefit from chemo. My score was 15 and my concologist and i decided against chemo because the risk outweighed the benefits.
Posts.Title: January 2012 rads Kate60 edoyrest

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2012 01:37PM Carrye wrote: 6 more then 5 boosts. My breast looked completely normal until about three weeks into the rads. Now the tumor bed area is very dark, the breast is very tanned, the hair follicles have darkened and stand out, and the crease under my 36 dd boob is itchy, dark and sensitive. I was prepped for boosts yesterday and have a circle of blue marker now around the scar/tumor bed. I am using aquaphor and 99% aloe vera. I hope i dont blister!
Posts.Title: January 2012 rads Kate60 edoyrest

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2012 05:28PM Carrye wrote: I got a custom mix of aquaphor and lidocaine from my radiation nurse today, as my burning, itching and sensitivity have worsened. I am hanging in there.
